```{.r .cell-code}
library(showtext)
library(ggtext)
library(viridis)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

StopAndSearchData <- read_csv("2022-09-metropolitan-stop-and-search.csv") %>%
  janitor::clean_names() #to remove spaces, upper case letters, etc. from variable names.

# View(StopAndSearchData)

updatedData <- StopAndSearchData %>%
            mutate(
                  # just the date without hour info
                  date_no_hour = as.Date(date), 
                  # get the year, month, etc
                  # just the date without hour info
                  date_no_hour = as.Date(date), 
                  # get the year, month, etc
                  year_ = year(date),
                  month_ = month(date),
                  month_name = month(date, label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE),
                  day_number = day(date),
                  weekday = wday(date, label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE)
                  )
# View(updatedData)

##################################################################################################

##### BAR CHART OF SEARCHES BY AGE RANGE TO SHOW WHICH AGE GROUPS ARE MOST FREQUENCTLY STOPPED AND SEARCHED
# separating into levels 
StopAndSearchData$age_range <- factor(StopAndSearchData$age_range, levels = c( "under 10", "10-17", "18-24", "25-34", "over 34" ))
# Removing NA values
StopAndSearchData <- StopAndSearchData %>% filter(!is.na(age_range))
# Create the bar chart with counts on top
ggplot(data = StopAndSearchData, aes(x = age_range)) + 
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +
  geom_text(stat = 'count', aes(label = ..count..), vjust = -0.5) +  # Add text labels on top of the bars
  labs(title = "18-24 year olds Stopped and Searched the most",
       subtitle = "Septemeber 2022", 
       x = "Age Ranges",
       y = "Number of Searches") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", color = "darkblue", hjust = 0.5),  
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, face = "italic", color = "gray", hjust = 0.5)  # Customizsing title and subtiltles
  )
```

###### STACKED BAR CHART BY OUTCOME & AGE RANGE 
# Removing NAs for age_range and outcome

  labs(title = "Usually no further action after Search across all ages (Sept 2022)",

       x = "Age Ranges",

## Trends & patterns in time of day and week

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
############ Heatmap of Searches by Day of the Week and Hour.
# Add an hour column to updatedData
updatedData <- updatedData %>%
  mutate(hour = hour(date))  # Extracting hour from date

# Summarising the data to count searches by day and hour
heatmap_data <- updatedData %>%
  group_by(weekday, hour) %>%
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = 'drop')

# creating the heatmap
ggplot(heatmap_data, aes(x = weekday, y = hour, fill = count)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white") +  # Use geom_tile to create the heatmap
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "inferno", # Fill with a continuous color scale
                       name = "Number of Searches", 
                       direction = -1,) + # Reverse the color direction (darker color --> more births)
  labs(
    title = "More searches during Late Evenings & End of the Week",
    subtitle = "Frequency of searches based on the day of the week and hour of the day (Sept 2022)",
    x = "Day of the Week",
    y = "Hour of the Day"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10, hjust = 0.5),
    
  )
```

## frequency of Stops

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
##### LINE GRAPH TO SHOW THE COUNT OF STOP & SEARCHES PER DAY of the month  
# Count stop-and-search activities by day
daily_searches <- updatedData %>%
  group_by(date_no_hour) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

# Plot the line graph
ggplot(data = daily_searches, aes(x = date_no_hour, y = count)) +
  geom_line(color = "darkblue") +
  labs(
    title = "Pretty consistent number of Stop-and-Search Activities",
    subtitle = "Trend of Stop-and-Search Activities (September 2022)",
    x = "Date",
    y = "Number of Searches"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, face = "italic", hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12)
  ) + 
  geom_smooth()
```
